What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:

options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to be a better person and care for the world + the value of listening/paying attention.

This course really changed the way that I thought about animals and the distinctions between humans and animals. It helped me question some of the assumptions that are made about animals/species in a lot of scientific fields and understand some of the limitations in the ways we commonly think about these things. I also gained more respect and consideration for animals that I hope I can carry through the rest of my studies.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
1. The books all relate to one another, and even though the reading load looks really heavy, Professor Dudley encourages students to read only the parts that interest them (even if that's not the entire book and only ~100 pages).

2. Professor Dudley creates her own story and builds themes throughout the course while guiding discussion in a way that's very organic and student-focused (instead of the professor very clearly saying "here's what you have to know"). She takes what we takeaway and moves the discussion along and ties all the books and discussions together very nicely.

3. Professor Dudley herself is a very kind and understanding professor who acknowledges that students are humans. Her insight is always spot-on. Professor Dudley not only doesn't discourage but actually encourages students to use personal voice (and to experiment with modes of sharing/writing). You will be pushed outside of your comfort zone and confront aspects of your life that may not be the best for the world, but I think everyone in the course came out of this course learning more about how we interact with the beings around us and how we can be better stewards to the world.

I really enjoyed our class discussions because the class was really centered on what we wanted to talk about. I also appreciate how we were not expected to finish the books that were assigned each week, but instead got to choose which parts interested us the most. While that did make it a little more confusing in discussion, I think it gave a lot of flexibility and allowed us to engage deeper with the parts we did choose to read.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the course worked very well. While it would've been nice to have the class in person, I think that we found a flow in our zoom discussions. I personally preferred the whole group discussion to breakout rooms, but that was mostly what we did. I also appreciated the opportunity to have TA meetings because those were super helpful!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Absolutely yes!! If you want a course that will change the way you live your life--in a way that is more caring, thoughtful, and attentive--then this is the course for you.

1. The books all relate to one another, and even though the reading load looks really heavy, Professor Dudley encourages students to read only the parts that interest them (even if that's not the entire book and only ~100 pages).

2. Professor Dudley creates her own story and builds themes throughout the course while guiding discussion in a way that's very organic and student-focused (instead of the professor very clearly saying "here's what you have to know"). She takes what we takeaway and moves the discussion along and ties all the books and discussions together very nicely.

3. Professor Dudley herself is a very kind and understanding professor who acknowledges that students are humans. Her insight is always spot-on. Professor Dudley not only doesn't discourage but actually encourages students to use personal voice (and to experiment with modes of sharing/writing). You will be pushed outside of your comfort zone and confront aspects of your life that may not be the best for the world, but I think everyone in the course came out of this course learning more about how we interact with the beings around us and how we can be better stewards to the world.

Yes definitely. It really expanded the way that I think about species and animals, especially as a biology student. I feel like there are a lot of things that we are taught in science classes that do come from a biased perspective and are never challenged, and this class helped me be more open-minded and willing to see some of these assumptions. I would definitely recommend it to someone studying animals or E&EB/ related sciences because of this, and would also just recommend it to anyone in general because it was really interesting.
YES! A hidden gem. One of the best courses Ive taken at Yale. The discussions were fascinating and the syllabus was amazing
